data.text: On 9 Nov the working group on risk-free rates hosted a Roundtable. Main purpose was to engage with market participants on the working group's recommendation for ESTER as the successor to EONIA. Watch our explainer to find out more about the next steps in the selection process and who has the final say on who will oversee banking supervision in Europe from 1 January 2019. https://t.co/9e5h6y2PGN
Andrea Enria, Chairperson of @EBA_News, nominated by the ECB to head supervision from 1 January 2019. Read more in our press release https://t.co/w7xzIW28MG https://t.co/hXQfic0UhZ
ECB nominates Andrea Enria as Chair of Supervisory Board https://t.co/VwCMzeuWzc
Read more about firms going digital in our latest Economic Bulletin article https://t.co/FBEBqakfaU 14/14

Our aim is to keep inflation low, which we define as being below, but close to, 2% over the medium term. This is so you can feel secure in the knowledge that the money in your pocket will go as far tomorrow as it does today. Read more https://t.co/dSRBljkCby 13/14
We at the ECB are interested in how #digitaltransformation affects productivity, competition and employment because these factors can affect inflation. 12/14

What about employment? Around a third of the companies surveyed expected digitalisation to reduce employment in their company over the next three years, while around a fifth foresaw increases in employment. 11/14
In contrast, service providers (especially retailers) were more inclined to see the adoption of digital technologies by others as reducing their sales prices. 10/14
However, to the extent that higher sales prices reflect a better product, this could in reality mean lower prices, as customers would be getting more for their money. 9/14
Looking separately at goods producers and service providers, producers of goods tended to see their own adoption of digital technologies as enabling them to increase prices. 8/14

What does digitalisation mean for the price customers pay? When asked how they expected the use of digital technologies – by their own company and by suppliers, competitors and customers – to affect prices, around 50% of firms expected little or no impact, or were unsure. 7/14

E-commerce, i.e. online shopping, makes it easier for firms and customers to find each other, while robotics and artificial intelligence increase automation, which leads to more efficient production. 6/14 https://t.co/wmJRYeVX6a

With this insight, firms can offer new or improved services and tailored, higher-quality solutions. This, in turn, supports improvements in the quality of existing products (in addition to purely technology-driven improvements). These improvements increase sales. 5/14 https://t.co/6Ff9GltfD7
Overall, the firms we talked to think these digital technologies have a positive impact on their sales and productivity. How? Let’s take a few examples. 3/14
First, what do we mean by #digitalisation? 2/14 https://t.co/WqqHJqlTEO

(THREAD) #Digitalisation is changing the way firms do business. Do firms, and ultimately customers, benefit? How does this affect the economy? We asked 74 leading eurozone firms what going digital means for sales, prices, productivity and employment. 1/14 https://t.co/4OgkPQFSc9

Our live webcast continues today until 14:00 CET. Tune in to watch Nobel Prize winner Jean Tirole discuss the concept of a lender of last resort at our joint conference with @NBB_BNB_FR, @SolvayEDU and @TSEinfo https://t.co/80aJmPSbO3 https://t.co/9eBhcA1F2H

The ECB bought public and private sector assets worth €15.0 billion in October under its expanded asset purchase programme. Take a look at our website for more detailed information https://t.co/0MN2pn9Waz https://t.co/Athq3dkbXG
Want to learn more about macroprudential policies and the role of the ECB? Check out our explainer https://t.co/xAN1xaiOZs 6/6

Luis de Guindos: While huge progress has been achieved, the banking union is unfortunately not yet complete. A European deposit insurance scheme is still missing. Such a risk-sharing arrangement would lead to further risk reduction and support financial stability. 5/6

Luis de Guindos: Ensuring stable conditions requires stronger regulation and sounder supervisory practices. It also involves pre-emptive macroprudential policies that limit the build-up of imbalances and increase resilience ahead of future stress events. 3/6

Luis de Guindos: Central banks have demonstrated that they can be effective crisis managers in times of stress, but they have often lacked the toolkit to pre-emptively address financial stability risks while they are building up. 2/6

We asked the speakers to present their work in under a minute! They discussed a wide range of topics such as the links between monetary policy and the banking sector, and the different ways we can rethink monetary policy theories today https://t.co/uFmfdfOAjR https://t.co/aTqek6XmjV

Nobel Prize winner Christopher A. Sims spoke about the links between monetary and fiscal policy, as both can affect inflation. Check out the full panel discussion here https://t.co/EidF9X39KO https://t.co/W7zQyMjyG4

On 29 and 30 October we hosted a conference on the theory and practice of monetary policy, where economists from universities and central banks from around the world gathered to share their views on the challenges facing monetary policy today https://t.co/Njn7d6nkhO https://t.co/ampx5wNyIZ

I’m off now – I hope you enjoyed this thread. We’d love to see replies with pictures of your carved pumpkin or other autumn scenes. It’s beautiful out there. #HappyHalloween everyone! 11/11 https://t.co/xM5CEMRfk8

Our economists and statisticians study price developments because our aim here at the ECB is to make sure inflation stays low, which we define as below, but close to, 2% over the medium term. Why and what does that mean for you? Read our explainer https://t.co/bIiiWwK04r 10/11

Ieva and Bernhard kindly gave me the specific info I was interested in, but in their work they follow price changes more broadly and over time, with more general data on everything we in the eurozone buy – from televisions to #Halloween costumes. 9/11 https://t.co/k34Ugo2Smg
I found this really interesting and I met one of our statisticians, Bernhard, to ask him why. He told me it's seasonal and is typical for vegetables. 6/11 https://t.co/FXz3qDb2Zl
Ieva’s data showed much more than this one figure. On average, the prices of pumpkins, aubergines and corn actually go up and down like a seesaw! #Halloween 5/11 https://t.co/EyxVcS5jCM

But this got me wondering how much I paid for a #Halloween pumpkin last year. Luckily for me, there are people here at the ECB I can ask about prices going up and down. One of our economists, Ieva, shared data with me which showed… 4/11 https://t.co/7O4aEM0PnJ
It cost me 5 euros. I thought this seemed a lot, but it is a huge pumpkin – I could barely carry it – so fair enough… #Halloween 3/11 https://t.co/esTnGlP82S
I bought this pumpkin the other day in my local supermarket in Frankfurt’s Nordend (a neighbourhood in the north of the city) and had a go at carving it. #Halloween 2/11 https://t.co/m13zxX0vgm
